channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Strange, Unending Limbo of Egypt’s Hosni Mubarak
item.media:description: Supporters of former President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt gathered outside Maadi Military Hospital, where the deposed leader is being held, to celebrate Sinai Liberation Day in Cairo last month.
item.description: The deposed leader remains confined to a hospital room in Cairo even as many former allies cut deals with the government to overturn their own convictions.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Another Baghdad Market Bombing, Claimed by ISIS, Kills Dozens
item.description: Two explosions at the market, in the predominantly Shiite neighborhood of Shaab, left at least 38 people dead, and many more wounded, officials said.
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and OMAR AL-JAWOSHY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: On Visit to Hong Kong, Beijing Official Draws Protest
item.media:description: Zhang Dejiang, chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People’s Congress, in Hong Kong on Tuesday.
item.description: The Politburo member is remembered for attempting to cover up the 2003 SARS outbreak when he was party chief of a neighboring province.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: Thailand Will Close a Popular Island to Tourists
item.media:description: Koh Tachai, Thailand. The Department of National Parks, Wildlife and Plant Conservation is closing the beaches, the reef and a tourist area on the island “to solve the environmental and natural resources impact which is caused by tourism.”
item.media:credit: Caine Delacy for The New York Times
item.description: The government says the action is necessary because Koh Tachai, famous for its white beaches and coral reefs, has deteriorated from abuse by hordes of visitors.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Kilinochchi Journal: Rebuilding Lives, and Homes, Shattered by Sri Lanka’s Civil War
item.media:description: The Ramasamys at their home in Kilinochchi, Sri Lanka.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Survivors of Sri Lanka’s 26-year conflict have slowly returned to the Kilinochchi area, after months or even years in government rehabilitation camps.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and DHARISHA BASTIANS

item.title: Top E.U. Official Calls Boris Johnson’s Remarks on E.U. and Hitler ‘Absurd’
item.media:description: The president of the European Council, Donald Tusk, left, at a news conference in Copenhagen on Tuesday, where he criticized the former mayor of London, Boris Johnson.
item.description: Donald Tusk said the former London mayor had “political amnesia” when he equated the European Union with the German dictator.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: News Analysis: Legacy of a Secret Pact Haunts Efforts to End War in Syria
item.description: No one was celebrating the centenary of the Sykes-Picot Agreement, which shaped the modern Middle East, as world diplomats gathered on Monday.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Wind Pushes Raging Alberta Blaze Back Toward Fort McMurray
item.media:description: A Canadian flag flying over a damage area of Fort McMurray, Canada. About 500 to 600 people were evacuated from work camps north of the city on Monday as the fire shifted its path.
item.media:credit: Chris Schwarz/Government of Alberta, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: New evacuations were in progress as the out-of-control blaze also appeared headed for two major oil sands projects north of the city.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Swedish Court Sentences Man to Life in Prison for Role in Rwanda Genocide
item.media:description: Claver Berinkindi, second from right, in court in Stockholm in September. Mr. Berinkindi received a life sentence from a Stockholm District Court for his participation in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda.
item.description: The Stockholm District Court found that Claver Berinkindi, who obtained Swedish citizenship in 2012, had participated in five massacres in 1994
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Asia: North Korea Is Said to Appoint Career Envoy as Foreign Minister
item.media:description: Ri Yong-ho, left, in Singapore in 2015. He was North Korea’s senior nuclear negotiator at the time.
item.description: North Korea has promoted Ri Yong-ho, a diplomat, to succeed Foreign Minister Ri Su-yong, a South Korean government official said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Australia to Lay Off Leading Scientist on Sea Levels
item.media:description: Ice off the western Antarctic Peninsula in March. Australia’s science agency is laying off 275 scientists as it shifts its focus away from climate research and toward more commercial projects.
item.description: The scientist, John Church, confirmed that he was one of 275 scientists that an Australian science agency said would be dismissed.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (Australia)

item.title: Much of World Suffers Not From Abuse of Painkillers, but Absence of Them
item.media:description: An H.I.V. patient cooling off at a treatment center on the outskirts of Yangon, Myanmar, in 2012. The use of opioid analgesics to relieve pain is low in Asia and much of the developing world.
item.description: While the United States struggles with a surge in addiction, an estimated 5.5 billion people live in countries with little or no access to opioid analgesics.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere: Excerpt From People’s Daily on the Cultural Revolution
item.media:description: Soldiers writing messages of support for Mao Zedong and the Communist Party on a blackboard in Beijing in June 1966.
item.description: The Communist Party newspaper said the lessons of the Cultural Revolution can help Chinese society advance.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: China Quietly Targets U.S. Tech Companies in Security Reviews
item.media:description: A security guard at an Apple store in Beijing. The Chinese government is subjecting Apple and other foreign tech companies to security reviews, requiring employees or executives to answer questions about products in person.
item.description: A committee with ties to the country’s military and security agencies is requiring foreign tech giants like Apple to answer questions about encryption and data storage.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Chinese Newspaper Breaks Silence on Cultural Revolution
item.media:description: Members of the Red Guards carried portraits of Mao Zedong as they paraded through the streets of Beijing in 1967.
item.description: Fifty years after the start of the revolution, the Communist Party’s main newspaper urged people to accept the past condemnation of the upheaval.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte, Philippines’ New Leader, Plans to Reinstate Death Penalty
item.description: Rodrigo Duterte, the nation’s presumptive president, said Monday that murderers, robbers and rapists should be hanged twice, until their heads are severed.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Iran’s Hard-Liners Crack Down on Models Not Wearing Head Scarves
item.media:description: Iranian women in Tehran last month. With the onset of higher spring temperatures, some women have sought to shed all or parts of the often stifling Islamic uniform, which has brought the morality police back onto the streets of the capital.
item.description: The hard-liners arrested eight women as part of an effort to assert control in a nation that is becoming increasingly urbane.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Ukraine’s Eurovision Win Rouses a Chorus of Anger and Suspicion in Russia
item.media:description: About a thousand fans, many bearing flowers, greeted the Ukrainian singer Susana Jamaladinova, who goes by the stage name Jamala, when she flew into Kiev after winning the Eurovision contest.
item.description: Russians are fulminating about an “information war” and blaming the United States after a Ukrainian beat their nation’s odds-on favorite in the song contest.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: U.S. and East Asia Allies Join Forces to Track North Korean Missiles
item.media:description: A training exercise held by American and South Korean armed forces in Pohang, South Korea, in March.
item.description: The United States, Japan and South Korea will conduct a drill next month using destroyers equipped with the Aegis radar system.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Donald Trump Hits Back at British Officials David Cameron and Sadiq Khan
item.media:description: Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, stood for a portrait at City Hall last week.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Donald J. Trump said he “will remember” critical and “very nasty” comments made by Mr. Cameron, Britain’s prime minister, and Mr. Khan, London’s mayor.
item.dc:creator: ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: Letter From Europe: Cloak of Secrecy Fuels Anxiety Over Trans-Atlantic Trade Talks
item.media:description: A protest in Brussels against the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. Opponents are pushing for greater transparency in the trade talks.
item.description: European opposition to a sweeping trade deal involving the United States has focused on the confidentiality surrounding the talks.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Kabul Journal: Attacks in Kabul Keep Wall Builders Busy, Turning City Into Labyrinth
item.media:description: Artists painted a mural on a blast wall in front of an Afghan National Police post in Kabul in March. Some blast walls in the city are 20 feet tall.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Bombings in Afghanistan’s capital have led companies to build taller blast walls, which blend into the landscape as part of the city’s identity.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Sinosphere: Readers Respond: The Cultural Revolution’s Lasting Imprint
item.media:description: Red Guards, bands of young militants mobilized by Mao Zedong as a vanguard of the Cultural Revolution, filing through Tiananmen Square in Beijing in October 1966.
item.media:credit: Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.description: Here are some recollections from readers when asked how their families were affected by the Cultural Revolution, a decade of political upheaval unleashed by Mao Zedong half a century ago.

item.title: Huge Protest Against Afghan Government Brings Kabul to a Halt
item.media:description: Thousands of protesters marched in Afghanistan’s capital on Monday in the country’s largest demonstration since 2014.
item.description: With factional tensions already high, ethnic Hazara protesters said a move to reroute an electricity transmission line was biased against them.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Palestinian Museum Prepares to Open, Minus Exhibitions
item.media:description: Visitors last week at the new Palestinian Museum in Birzeit in the West Bank. It will open its doors on Wednesday despite being empty.
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.description: A $24 million building will open in the West Bank on Wednesday, but its inaugural display was suspended after a disagreement between its board and its director, who lost his position.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ and RAMI NAZZAL

item.title: What in the World: In Finland, a Postal Worker Will Mow Your Lawn
item.media:description: Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor untidy grass will stop Finnish couriers.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photos by Charles Brutlag, Mega Pixel, Claudio Divizia/Shutterstock
item.description: Stamp sales have slumped in the digital era, so postal services are trying new ways to earn revenue — some of them far afield from carrying the mail.
item.dc:creator: JAKE DOHERTY

item.title: What in the World: The Mountain That Tops Everest (Because the Earth Is Fat)
item.media:description: Earth flattens at its poles and bulges slightly around its waistline, making its radius about 13 miles greater at the Equator.
item.description: Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador rises about 20,500 feet above sea level, far short of Everest’s 29,029 feet. But it’s a different story when you measure from the center of the Earth.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: What in the World: Japan Has a Kit Kat for Every Taste, and Then Some
item.media:credit: Illustration by Craig Allen; Photos by Nestlé Japan
item.description: There are nearly 300 varieties of Kit Kat in Japan, where the candy is so popular that it is sold at high-end department stores, Kit Kat-only shops and even post offices.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Know-Nothing Tide
item.description: Trump says America was strongest when “politics ended at water's edge.” He's wrong.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Docs: Errol Morris: ‘Demon in the Freezer’
item.description: Smallpox has inflicted untold suffering and death. So why are we keeping it around?
item.dc:creator: ERROL MORRIS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Refugees Shouldn’t Be Bargaining Chips
item.description: The European Union paid off Turkey to take back desperate people. Now Kenya and other countries want their cut.
item.dc:creator: BEN RAWLENCE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
